> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
>> That is, how do we know that the champions
>> from experiments such as double pole-balancing or the robot duels could
>> not perform as well with 25% or more of their topology removed?

On Mon, 03 May 2004 20:27:47 -0000, Kenneth Stanley
<kstanley@...> wrote:
> I think this is missing the point, though.  This is exactly the
> perspective I was trying to argue we should change.  The question is
> not whether it could perform as well with 25% less structure, but
> why would we care if it did?  
<snip>
> What's important is that on average
> over all of evolution we are minimizing the space we have to search
> through.

Right.  Why would we care if our resultant champions have 25%
unnecessary topology?  Because we wouldn't be minimizing the space we
have to search through very effectively.

If you have a significant number of members of the population that are
unnecessarily complex, that's going to reduce the efficiency of your
search, right?

Derek
